Centro Internacional de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo

title.narrative: Renforcement de la direction des écoles en vue d’améliorer leur résilience
Strengthening school leadership towards improving school resiliency

description.narrative:
Les chefs d’établissement sont essentiels pour renforcer la résilience des écoles face aux menaces de santé publique, aux catastrophes naturelles, aux conflits armés, aux crises politiques et économiques et autres bouleversements. Ils sont essentiels pour soutenir l’amélioration de l’enseignement et de l’apprentissage en motivant les enseignants et les élèves, en créant des environnements scolaires adaptés, en comprenant les conditions locales et en servant de médiateur avec les collectivités qu’ils servent. Toutefois, dans de nombreux pays en développement, les directeurs d’école sont mal formés et se concentrent souvent sur des tâches de gestion plutôt que sur la direction de l’enseignement.
L’objectif de ce projet est de contribuer à l’amélioration de la qualité et de l’équité de l’apprentissage continu et du bien-être des filles et des garçons dans les pays du Sud pendant les fermetures prolongées des écoles en raison de la crise COVID-19 et les crises à venir. Il vise à renforcer les pratiques des chefs d’établissement dans une série de contextes à faibles ressources en prenant des décisions fondées sur des données. Pour ce faire, on établira dans quelle mesure une approche mixte en ligne/hors-ligne aide les responsables scolaires à apporter des changements pédagogiques dans leurs systèmes scolaires, en mettant l’accent sur les pratiques numériques.
Ce projet se déroulera aux Philippines, au Kenya et dans un autre pays d’Afrique subsaharienne. Ces pays sont préoccupés par les faibles niveaux de réussite de certains groupes d’élèves et souhaitent renforcer le rôle pédagogique des chefs d’établissement et améliorer les pratiques numériques dans l’enseignement. Ils représentent également une série de voies vers la direction de l’école et des degrés d’autonomie dans ce rôle, maximisant ainsi les effets positifs d’ensemble qui peuvent résulter du projet.

School leaders are pivotal in building the resilience of schools in the face of public health threats, natural disasters, armed conflict, political and economic crises, and other upheavals. They are critical in supporting improved teaching and learning through motivating teachers and students, creating enabling school environments, understanding local conditions, and mediating with the communities they serve. But school leaders in many developing countries receive little preparation for their role and frequently focus on managerial tasks rather than instructional leadership.
The objective of this project is to contribute to improved quality and equity of the continued learning and wellbeing of girls and boys in the Global South during the prolonged school closures of the COVID-19 crisis and future emergencies. It aims to strengthen the practices of school leaders in a range of low-resource contexts using data-driven decision-making. It will do so by establishing the extent to which a blended online/offline approach helps school leaders to effect pedagogic change in their school systems, with a focus on digital practices.
This project will take place in the Philippines, Kenya, and another country in sub-Saharan Africa. These countries share a concern with low levels of attainment among sub-groups of students, and a desire to strengthen the instructional role of school leaders and to enhance digital practices in education. They also represent a range of pathways to school leadership and degrees of autonomy in the role, thus maximizing the global good that can result from the project.

title.narrative: Schooling without barriers: improving education in the West Bank and Gaza during the COVID-19 pandemic
Scolarisation sans barrières : améliorer l’éducation en Cisjordanie et à Gaza pendant la pandémie de COVID-19

description.narrative:
La pandémie de COVID-19 a entraîné la fermeture d’écoles et l’interruption des cours, touchant 1,3 milliard d’enfants dans le monde. Cette interruption de l’apprentissage a des conséquences considérables aujourd’hui et pour l’avenir, avec des effets néfastes sur le développement cognitif, scolaire et socio-émotionnel des élèves. Elle a également bloqué, voire inversé, les progrès en matière d’apprentissage. En outre, elle a réduit le niveau d’éducation des enfants marginalisés tels que les réfugiés et les personnes déplacées, les filles et les enfants handicapés.
Nulle part ces défis ne sont ressentis avec autant d’acuité que dans les pays à faible revenu et fragiles comme la Cisjordanie et Gaza. Bien que les fermetures d’écoles généralisées dues à la pandémie finiront par passer, les urgences potentielles à l’horizon mettent en évidence un besoin urgent de données probantes sur les stratégies efficaces d’enseignement à distance et les moyens de faire face aux conséquences négatives des fermetures d’écoles.
Ce projet vise à répondre à cette crise en s’attaquant à la qualité de l’éducation dispensée aux enfants en dehors de l’école et en améliorant la capacité des enseignants à utiliser les outils d’enseignement à distance. L’objectif est d’étayer les politiques éducatives, notamment en ce qui concerne la fourniture de contenu, la formation des enseignants et la socialisation en vue de préparer les futures situations d’urgence.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to school closures and disruptions affecting 1.3 billion children worldwide. This disruption in learning has considerable consequences now and well into the future, with negative impacts on the cognitive, academic, and socio-emotional development of students. It has also stalled or even reversed learning gains. Further, it has reduced the educational attainment of marginalized children such as refugees and the internally displaced, girls, and children with disabilities.
Nowhere are these challenges felt more acutely than in low-income and fragile countries like the West Bank and Gaza. Though the widespread school closures of the pandemic will eventually pass, the potential future emergencies on the horizon highlight a pressing need for evidence on effective approaches to distance learning and ways of addressing the negative consequences of school closures.
This project seeks to respond to this crisis by addressing the quality of education provided to children while out of school and by improving teachers’ ability to use online environments for education. The aim is to inform education policies, including content delivery, teacher training, and socialization in preparation for future emergencies.

title.narrative: Soutien à l’examen externe de l’appel à propositions de recherche d’AE – Systèmes alimentaires et COVID-19 : Évaluation des réponses
Supporting the external review of AE’s Call for Research Proposals - Food Systems and COVID-19: Assessing the responses

description.narrative:
En juin 2020, le CRDI a lancé un appel à propositions de recherche visant à financer des activités de recherche dans le contexte de la pandémie de COVID-19. Lancé dans le cadre de l’Initiative d’intervention de recherche rapide du CRDI, ce projet a pour objectif d’aider à documenter et à analyser la manière dont les réactions aux chocs économiques et sanitaires associés à la COVID-19 ont protégé et/ou sapé la production et la disponibilité des aliments, et l’accès à la nourriture, en particulier pour les femmes et les personnes les plus vulnérables.
Ce projet prendra en charge les coûts liés à l’examen externe et au processus de sélection des propositions de recherche soumises dans le cadre de l’appel. Le CRDI recherche des examinateurs ayant une expertise dans les priorités thématiques déterminées dans l’appel (par exemple, sexospécificité et diversité, nutrition, systèmes alimentaires, production alimentaire et résilience, marchés alimentaires formels et informels, et impact sur les femmes et autres groupes vulnérables, etc.), et ayant une connaissance avérée du contexte local et régional des régions géographiques couvertes par l’initiative. L’objectif est de soutenir et de renforcer l’efficacité du processus d’examen des propositions.
L’objectif de l’engagement d’évaluateurs externes est d’obtenir une évaluation d’experts indépendante, objective et transparente des propositions soumises aux fins de financement, y compris une perspective objective sur les objectifs proposés, les résultats attendus, l’approche innovante et, enfin, la contribution potentielle du projet dans le domaine des systèmes alimentaires résilients en Afrique subsaharienne. Les résultats de ces examens fourniront une rétroaction et des recommandations clés au comité d’examen interne qui prend les décisions finales de financement, sur la base d’autres données d’évaluation et stratégiques.

In June 2020, IDRC launched a call for research proposals aimed to finance research activities in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. Initiated as part of IDRC’s broader Rapid Research Response Initiative, the objective of this project is to help document and analyze how responses to the economic and health shocks associated with COVID-19 have been protecting and/or undermining food production, availability, and access, particularly for women and the most vulnerable.
This project will support the costs associated with the external review and selection process of research proposals submitted as part of the call. IDRC seeks reviewers with expertise in the thematic priorities identified in the call (e.g. gender and diversity, nutrition, food systems, food production and resilience, formal and informal food markets, and impact on women and other vulnerable groups, etc.), and with proven knowledge of the local and regional context of the geographical regions covered by the initiative. The aim is to support and enhance the effectiveness of the proposal review process.
The aim of engaging external reviewers is to obtain an independent, objective, and transparent expert assessment of the proposals submitted for funding, including an objective perspective on the proposed goals, expected results, innovative approach, and ultimately the potential contribution of the project to the field of resilient food systems in sub-Saharan Africa. The results of the reviews will provide key feedback and recommendations to the internal review committee that makes the final decisions of funding, based on other evaluative and strategic information.

title.narrative: Soutien à la Conférence canadienne sur la santé mondiale 2020
Support to Canadian Conference on Global Health 2020

description.narrative:
Le programme Santé des mères et des enfants du CRDI (ainsi que le précédent programme) ont soutenu financièrement la Conférence canadienne sur la santé mondiale (CCSM), dirigée par la Société canadienne de santé internationale depuis plus de dix ans. Depuis 2017, l’initiative Innovation pour la santé des mères et des enfants d’Afrique (ISMEA) contribue également à ce soutien. L’ISMEA est une initiative d’une durée de sept ans financée à hauteur de 36 millions de dollars par Affaires mondiales Canada, le CRDI et les Instituts de recherche en santé du Canada (IRSC).
Le thème de la CCSM 2020 est « La santé mondiale face au changement climatique », les thèmes transversaux étant l’équité et l’innovation. En réponse aux restrictions mises en place en raison de la pandémie de COVID-19, la conférence se tiendra virtuellement du 19 au 22 octobre 2020. Elle comprendra des séances plénières, des symposiums, des ateliers, des séances spéciales, des forums interactifs, ainsi que des présentations orales et par affiches. Cette année, on renoncera aux frais de participation pour tous les participants des pays à faibles revenus et à revenus intermédiaires.
La CCSM est la grande conférence sur la santé mondiale au Canada. Chaque année, elle offre aux Canadiens travaillant dans le domaine de la santé mondiale l’espace le plus important pour se rencontrer et échanger entre eux, ainsi qu’avec des collègues du monde entier.

The Maternal and Child Health program (and its predecessor) have financially supported the Canadian Conference for Global Health (CCGH) run by the Canadian Society for International Health (CSIH) for more than ten years. Since 2017 the Innovating for Maternal and Child Health in Africa (IMCHA) initiative has also contributed to that support.
The theme for 2020 is “Global health in a changing climate”. Cross cutting themes include equity and innovation. Responding to the restrictions due to the COVID 19 pandemic, the conference will be held virtually October 19-22, 2020. It will have plenary sessions and symposia as well as workshops, special sessions, interactive forums, and oral and poster sessions. Participation fees for all low- and middle-income countries (LMIC) participants will be waived this year.
CCGH is the major global health conference in Canada and is the primary space for Canadians working in global health to connect annually with each other and with colleagues around the world. CCGH engages health care practitioners, researchers, academics, educators, policy makers, and community advocates. Considering the delegates who attend, CCGH is an ideal location to showcase IMCHA’s work.
Supporting CCGH2020 will contribute to increased visibility of IMCHA, including through three confirmed dedicated concurrent sessions. The conference will also create a space to share other IMCHA products such as the legacy videos. Furthermore, IDRC is invited to speak at a plenary session.

title.narrative: Monitoring, evaluation, and learning support to the SERRC Initiative
Suivi, évaluation et soutien de l’apprentissage dans le cadre de l’initiative Réponse sociale et économique et reprise après la COVID-19

description.narrative:
En avril 2020, le CRDI a lancé un appel à propositions dans le cadre d’un mécanisme de financement à réponse rapide permettant à des organismes particuliers d’apporter des recherches, des constatations et des données pour des solutions politiques et pratiques afin d’atténuer les conséquences sociales et économiques de la pandémie de COVID-19 et de promouvoir la reprise dans les pays à faible revenu. À la suite de l’appel, une cohorte de 21 projets regroupant des think tanks ainsi que des organismes de recherche du Sud ont été approuvés aux fins d’un financement dans le cadre du mécanisme, qu’on appelle maintenant « l’initiative Réponse sociale et économique et reprise après la COVID-19 ».
Parallèlement à ces projets de recherche, le CRDI appuie une stratégie de suivi, d’évaluation et d’apprentissage (MEL) afin de permettre l’adoption d’une approche à l’échelle de la cohorte en matière d’apprentissage institutionnel, d’adaptation, de rapports complets et de résultats mesurables. Compte tenu de la propagation régionale considérable et de l’éventail des points d’entrée dans le cadre de l’initiative Réponse sociale et économique et reprise après la COVID-19, le rôle de soutien de MEL sera essentiel pour saisir les répercussions à l’échelle de la cohorte, tout en reconnaissant la diversité des contextes, des régions et des objectifs. Les activités comprendront le peaufinement d’une voie d’impact, l’élaboration d’outils de rapport technique, et la fourniture de rapports de synthèse des conclusions obtenues durant les périodes visées par le rapport technique.

In April 2020, IDRC launched a call for proposals under a rapid-response funding mechanism to specific organizations to contribute to research, evidence, and data for policy and practice solutions to mitigate the social and economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and to promote recovery in low-income countries. Following the call, a cohort of 21 projects with think tanks and research organizations from the Global South were approved for funding under the mechanism, now referred to as the Social and Economic Response and Recovery from COVID (SERRC) Initiative.
Alongside those research projects, IDRC is supporting a monitoring, evaluation, and learning (MEL) strategy to allow for a cohort-wide approach to institutional learning, adaptation, comprehensive reporting, and measurable results. Given the considerable regional spread and range of entry points under the SERRC Initiative, the MEL support role will be critical in capturing cohort-level impacts while recognizing the diversity in contexts, regions, and objectives. Activities will include refining an impact pathway, developing technical reporting tools, and providing synthesis reports of findings from technical reporting periods.

title.narrative: The impacts of COVID-19 responses on the political economy of African food systems (COVID-19-AFS)
Évaluer les répercussions des réponses à la COVID-19 sur l’économie politique des systèmes alimentaires en Afrique (COVID-19 et SAA)

description.narrative:
IDRC’s response to the COVID-19 crisis includes a rapid response to the food and nutritional security crisis associated with COVID-19. This response mechanism supports the development of new, short-term activities that supplement existing projects. The goals are to document the impact of the pandemic (and control measures) on local food systems and food security; to document planned and spontaneous responses to the emerging crisis; and to strengthen responses to the current crisis. The rapid response mechanism also supports the development of new projects that document and analyze the efficacy of those responses. This will help low- and middle-income countries respond more efficiently to subsequent waves of the epidemic and to potential future shocks.
This project aims to implement action-oriented research on the impacts of COVID-19 interventions on the functioning and structure of food systems in Tanzania, Ghana, and South Africa. These three countries cover a spectrum of different economies, food systems, and COVID-19 responses. The research team will collect and analyze information across formal and informal food systems using a mixed-methods approach. By mapping food flows, key informant interviews, ethnographic field and online research, and collecting voice notes and video material, the project will gain a real-time understanding of the direct impacts of regulatory responses on production systems, value chains, and formal and informal markets by focusing on women and marginalized actors. The findings will be packaged and disseminated for policy, advocacy, and academic purposes.

La réponse du Centre de recherches pour le développement international à la crise de la COVID-19 comprend une réponse rapide à la crise de sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle associée à cette pandémie. Ce mécanisme de réponse soutient la création de nouvelles activités à court terme qui complètent les projets existants. Les objectifs consistent à documenter les répercussions de la pandémie (et les mesures de contrôle) sur les systèmes alimentaires locaux et la sécurité alimentaire, à documenter les réponses planifiées et spontanées à la crise émergente, et à renforcer les réponses à la crise actuelle. Le mécanisme de réponse rapide soutient également l’élaboration de nouveaux projets qui documentent et analysent l’efficacité de ces réponses. Cela aidera les pays à revenu faible ou intermédiaire à répondre plus efficacement aux vagues ultérieures de l’épidémie et à d’éventuels chocs futurs.
Ce projet vise à mettre en œuvre une recherche orientée vers l’action et portant sur les effets qu’ont les interventions liées à la COVID-19 sur le fonctionnement et la structure des systèmes alimentaires en Tanzanie, au Ghana et en Afrique du Sud. Ces trois pays représentent un éventail d’économies, de systèmes alimentaires et de réponses à la COVID-19 différents. L’équipe de recherche recueillera et analysera des renseignements sur les systèmes alimentaires formels et informels en utilisant une approche mixte. En cartographiant les flux alimentaires, en interrogeant des informateurs clés, en effectuant des recherches ethnographiques sur le terrain et en ligne, et en recueillant des notes vocales et du matériel vidéo, le projet permettra de comprendre en temps réel les effets directs des réponses réglementaires sur les systèmes de production, les chaînes de valeur et les marchés formels et informels en se concentrant sur les femmes et les acteurs marginalisés. Les résultats seront formatés et diffusés à des fins d’établissement de politiques, de sensibilisation et pédagogiques.

title.narrative: Documenter la zone de planification spéciale et le processus de réaménagement du quartier informel de Mukuru à Nairobi
Documenting the special planning area and redevelopment process in Nairobi’s Mukuru informal settlement

description.narrative:
Les habitants du quartier informel de Mukuru, qui abrite environ 10 % de la population de Nairobi, ont dû faire face à de nombreux défis pour accéder aux services (eau, électricité, logement et éducation) et à des droits fonciers sûrs. Après des années de recherche à impact élevé et d’interactions fructueuses avec les autorités locales et nationales, l’administration du comté de Nairobi a déclaré l’établissement d’une zone de planification spéciale pour Mukuru en août 2017. La zone de planification spéciale a gelé le développement à Mukuru tandis qu’un consortium de quarante organisations locales a élaboré un plan d’aménagement intégré. Ces derniers mois, dans le cadre de leur réponse à la pandémie de COVID-19, les Services métropolitains de Nairobi ont commencé à mettre en œuvre ce plan et alloué 12 millions de dollars pour le développement des infrastructures pendant l’exercice en cours.
Ce projet soutiendra les efforts de l’Akiba Mashinani Trust pour documenter et diffuser les enseignements tirés d’un processus novateur et transformationnel visant à réaménager le quartier informel de Mukuru. Par le biais de recherches sur le terrain, de réunions de mobilisation stratégique, d’ateliers et d’événements de diffusion, le projet vise à saisir les premiers efforts de mise en œuvre du plan de réaménagement de la zone de planification spéciale. En documentant les leçons retenues et les pratiques exemplaires émergentes, ces efforts d’application des connaissances cherchent à saisir, d’une part, l’histoire complète de la zone de planification spéciale et à la raconter du point de vue des personnes qui en étaient les plus proches. La priorité sera accordée à la saisie des expériences uniques en leur genre de différents groupes, comme le leadership des femmes et des jeunes au fil des ans. D’autre part, des activités sont prévues pour communiquer des constatations à des publics mondiaux dans le but d’améliorer les approches en matière de planification et de gouvernance urbaines dans des contextes de pauvreté urbaine et d’informalité généralisées.

Residents of the Mukuru informal settlement, home to approximately 10% of Nairobi’s population, have faced many challenges in gaining access to services (water, electricity, housing, and schooling) and secure land tenure. After years of high-impact research and successful engagement with local and national authorities, the Nairobi County government declared a special planning area for Mukuru in August 2017. The special planning area froze development in Mukuru while a consortium of forty local organizations developed an integrated development plan. In recent months, as part of its response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Nairobi Metropolitan Services has started implementing the plan and allocated $12 million for infrastructure development during the current financial year.
This project will support the efforts of Akiba Mashinani Trust to document and disseminate lessons learned from an innovative and transformational process to redevelop the Mukuru informal settlement. Through field research, policy engagement meetings, workshops, and dissemination events, the project aims to capture first efforts to implement the special planning area redevelopment plan. In capturing lessons learned and emerging best practices, these knowledge translation efforts seek, on one level, to capture the full history of the special planning area story and tell it from the perspectives of the people who were closest to it. Priority will be placed on capturing unique experiences of different groups, like the leadership of women and youth populations over the years. On another level, activities are planned to share findings with global audiences, with the aim of improving urban planning and governance approaches in contexts of widespread urban poverty and informality.

title.narrative: DMDP 2016 – MYPOD Work environment, productivity and social dialogue in Myanmar garment industry

description.narrative: In partnership with Bestseller, 3F and Aalborg University, Danish Ethical Trading Initiative (DIEH) aims to improve the quality of jobs and create sustainable increased value addition and participation in the global garment value chain. The MYPOD project was launched in 2017, and redesigned in 2020 to respond to developments in the industry and the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Project activities include training and capacity-building on sector level of workers’ representatives, workers, factory management and industry stakeholders on freedom of association, social dialogue and occupational health and safety. The trainings will be developed together with trade union federations in Myanmar, and facilitated through printed and digital media, as well as workshops. Project activities are coordinated to contribute to ongoing initiatives in the Myanmar garment sector, such as the implementation of the Myanmar Guideline on Freedom of Association (FOA), agreed in November 2019 by delegates of the Employer Working Group producing in Myanmar for ACT member brands, and the Industrial Workers’ Federation of Myanmar (IWFM) affiliated with the Confederation of Trade Unions of Myanmar (CTUM) and IndustriALL Global Union, as well as initiatives by the Myanmar Joint Action Group. As an outcome of the project, workers and employers can benefit from improved social dialogue capacity – also at sector level – where workers’ rights are more respected, workers’ health and safety are better protected, and work environment and productivity are improved – all of which contribute to more decent jobs. The Danida Market Development Partnerships programme (DMDP) is designed to support commercially oriented partnerships for sustainable market development in developing countries. In addition to reporting on individually determined outputs and outcomes, all DMDP projects report on five key programme indicators. These five indicators are the same for the whole project portfolio, enabling strategi
Myanmar’s garment industry will generate more decent jobs, sustainable increased value addition and participation in the global garment value chain.

title.narrative: Oplysningspuljen 2020

description.narrative:
1) Oplysningsprojekter 14,3 mio. kr. 2) Administrationsomkostninger 1,7 mio. kr. 3) Verdensbilledlegatet 1,3 mio. kr.
1) Tilskud til oplysningsprojekter, herunder også undervisningsmaterialer, til den brede danske befolkning om forhold i vækst- og udviklingslandene. 2-3 ansøgningsrunder pr. år. Alle projekter over 50.000 kr. vurderes af udvalget. Projekter under 50.000 kan vurderes på sekretariatsniveau.
2) Administration, drift og udvikling af Oplysningspuljen, herunder udgifter til det eksterne udvalg (honorar), udgifter relateret til udvalgsmøder, IT-udgifter inkl. licens til TAS.
3) Videokonkurrence blandt studerende om rejselegater til et vækst- eller udviklingsland. Verdensbilledlegatet blev ikke afholdt i 2020 pga COVID-19. Konkurrencen projetledes eksternt (Buchs A/S).
Rammen for formidlingen til den danske befolkning er verdensmålene. Det er en forudsætning for støtte, at rejsemålene og det land/de lande, som et oplysningsprojekt har fokus på, er i overensstemmelse med DAC-listen.

title.narrative: UNICEF COVID-19 Appeal 2020

description.narrative: Danish contribution to UNICEF's COVID-19 Appeal 2020
N/A

UN Children's Fund (UNICEF) COVID-19 appeal: DKK 50.0 million DKK. UNICEF has launched a global COVID-19 appeal of 293.5 million. DKK. The organization is a leading member of the UN Crisis Management Team and as such is an important player in the WHO's emergency coordination. The focus of the effort is i.a. on strengthened access to clean water and sanitation, dissemination of information on infection control measures in vulnerable households and local communities, distribution of hygiene equipment to schools and medicines, etc. to health clinics, as well as general support for children in areas affected by infection. These are all key elements in the overall effort in relation to the spread of COVID-19 in poor and vulnerable countries. There will be a special focus on refugee children.
https://www.unicef.org/reports

title.narrative: Denmark's contribution to WHO COVID-19 SPRP

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

The contribution is given towards the activities of WHO's Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan (SPRP) and it's ODA eligible activities. SPRP outlines the public health measures that the international community stands ready to provide to support all countries to prepare for and respond to COVID-19. Denmark's contribution will be used primarily for countries listed under Levels 1-3 of WHO’s SPRP Country Preparedness and Response Status for COVID-19 (version 9 April 2020), with the exemption of Cook Island.

title.narrative: UNHCR COVID-19 2020

description.narrative: Danish contribution to UNHCR's share of the COVID-19 Global Humanitarian Response Plan, 2020

FN’s Flygtningeorganisation (UNHCR)’s andel af den globale humanitære Covid-19 appel er på 1,8 mia. kr. UNHCR spiller en helt central rolle i at sikre den nødvendige forebyggelse blandt flygtninge og internt fordrevne, og at de får adgang til nødvendige sundhedsydelser og anden humanitær støtte, når og hvis COVID-19 rammer de områder, hvor de opholder sig. Flygtninge og internt fordrevne falder meget ofte uden for normale offentlige systemer, enten fordi de ikke har ret til at bruge dem, eller fordi de ganske enkelt ikke findes i tilstrækkeligt omfang. Forebyggelsesindsatser vil f.eks. have fokus på oplysningskampagner om smittebegrænsende adfærd, og eks. styrket adgang til rent vand med håndvaske-faciliteter. Samtidig fokuseres på at få forberedt humanitære sundhedsydelser bedst muligt, eks. ved at bygge isolationsfaciliteter og sikre leverancer af værnemidler. UNHCR arbejder pt med 24 prioritetslande med særligt fokus på 10-12 situationer, hvor risikoen for en spredning af pandemien vurderes er særligt høj. Det gælder bl.a. Mali, Sudan, Sydsudan, Somalia, Libyen, Syrien og Afghanistan samt flygtninge i nabolande til disse.

title.narrative: Denmark's Contribution to WHO COVID-19 GHRP

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

The COVID-19 Global Humanitarian Response Plan (GHRP) is a comprehensive inter-agency response plan that aggregates and updates relevant existing humanitarian appeals from UN and non-UN entities, including WFP, WHO, IOM, UNDP, UN-Habitat, UNFPA, UNHCR, UNICEF and taking into consideration the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement. The Plan focuses on preparedness and response to the initial immediate and urgent health and non-health needs and response to the pandemic, including to secure supply chains and humanitarian personnel mobility. The project will only cover WHO's activities under the GHRP.

title.narrative: CEPI core contribution 2020

description.narrative: Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations - CEPI - is not-for-profit and works to ensure a fair access to vaccines, surmountable prices and availability in areas that are most affected by new and emerging diseases – in particular low income countries. CEPI works in close partnership with WHO and the World Bank and has become one of the lead actors on vaccine development – both in regards to preparedness, but also to response and immediate needs such as the COVID-19 pandemic – and has the institutional expertise, networks, and agility to move rapidly.

FL §06.38.02.12 Partnerships for market-based growth

title.narrative: Women Deliver - Bridging Grant 2020

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

The strategic objective is, by various means of advocacy, to reach and influence key decision-makers, and promote the uptake of data-driven recommendations on policies and investments related to gender equality in key international NGOs, UN Agencies and countries, with the aim to accelerate progress towards improving the health and rights of women and girl globally and in developing countries. The objective will be achieved through 1) communication and advocacy materials developed and disseminated in Kenya and globally that contribute to shifting the narrative to prioritize gender equality and girls and women’s health and rights, 2) Technical support on gender equality and girls’ and women’s health and rights, including SRHR and the COVID-19 response and recovery, provided to UN agencies and through Women Deliver participation on key task forces and initiatives, and 3) Support to networks of advocates, in order to push for progress on gender equality and girls’ and women’s health and rights, including in the COVID-19 response and recovery, globally and in Kenya.

title.narrative: Sahel Adaptive Social Protection Programme (COVID-19), engagement

description.narrative: Danmark kan afhjælpe konsekvenser af COVID-19 for de meste sårbare grupper ved at bidrage til at udbygge de sparsomme sociale sikkerhedsnet i Sahel. Indsatsen vil afhjælpe udfordringer på kort sigt (3-6 måneder), såsom sult, og samtidig opbygge kapacitet til at imødegå fremtidige chok som følge af klimaforandringer (tørke/oversvømmelser), konflikt, fordrivelse og irregulær migration. De sociale sikkerhedsnet har særligt fokus på at styrke tilpasningsevne til chok og bidrager fx med kontantbaseret hjælp og jobskabelse m.v. At kunne nå de mest sårbare, herunder personer med handicap, er en af hovedprioriteterne med sociale sikkerhedsnet.

title.narrative: Evaluating legal and policy responses to COVID-19 from a HR perspective in developing countries

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

The project is focused on the state of human rights during the COVID-19 pandemic. RWI will undertake a systematic analysis of human rights implications of COVID-19 response and recovery measures in 15 developing countries. The main outputs of the project will be: a refined tool that facilitates constructive engagement with states on the human rights implications of legal and policy measures adopted in response to COVID-19, 15 national law and policy reports addressing the human rights-implications of COVID-19 response in the selected developing countries, a comparative analysis of good practices and issues of concern, and a global webinar. The project will lay the foundation for a more ambitious global initiative, which will provide agenda-setting for the post-pandemic world, as well as capacity building for national researchers and other actors, and a wider analysis of policy responses to the pandemic worldwide.

title.narrative: Center for Global Development Partnership 2020-2023

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

This partnership aims to provide real-time analysis, evidence-based solutions, and actionable recommendations to help policymakers and other stakeholders mitigate the impact of COVID-19 in LMICs and prepare for future global pandemics.
The partnership will focus on three cross-cutting and overarching objectives: a) Advancing a more resilient global health system and fit-for-purpose preparedness and response infrastructure for LMICs: b) Strengthening global health supply chains and promoting sustainable models for global health innovation and access to make markets work better for the poor in LMICs c) Advancing an effective and coordinated international response to economic challenges in LMICs

title.narrative: Center for Global Development Partnership 2020-2023, engagement

description.narrative: In an effort to inform LMIC governments, members of the development community, and other stakeholders responding to the ongoing pandemic, CGD experts will produce knowledge products outlining and urging greater policy coherence among multilateral institutions, LMIC governments, bilateral donors, and the broader global health community in the response to COVID-19. Throughout the grant period, CGD’s work will focus on strengthening the resiliency of the global health system more broadly and preparing for future pandemics.

title.narrative: DMDP 2020 - SEGES, Indonesien

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

Pilot Market Driven Organic Dairy Production in Indonesia (MDOD)
The project is a partnership between Arla, ICBP/Indolakto, SEGES/DAFC and Bina Swadaya. Partners have complementary capacity covering all aspects of the dairy value chain and responsible business conduct. The objective is to pilot a market driven and sustainable organic dairy production and to increase milk productivity as well as economic output of the dairy value chain in Indonesia. Interventions are designed to increase revenues at farm, dairy, sales and distribution levels, and to increase the number of decent jobs all along the dairy value chain, incl. on-farm jobs. Farmers converting to organic milk production, will be linked to a commercially viable and ‘green’ dairy value chain increasing their net income post COVID-19. The project is fully in line with governmental priorities of organic milk production. Focus is on farmers in East Java, but the model is scalable to other regions in Indonesia.

title.narrative: DMDP 2020 - BRAC, Bangladesh

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

Safe water for all: a new partnership for growth in Bangladesh
This project’s development objective is to create inclusive and sustainable economic growth, increased income through improved and new jobs in water treatment and distribution (SDGs 1 and 8), and to increase access to safe and affordable drinking water for people in Bangladesh (SDG6) - supporting with economic recovery from Covid-19. The business objective is for Grundfos and Hydro to expand their businesses in the Bangladesh safe water market by creating a commercially viable business partnership model (SDG9) for cleaning industrial effluent (SDG12), reducing the harmful impacts of effluent on people and the environment (SDG3) and delivering safe drinking water (SDG6) whilst creating green jobs and additional income (SDG8) in the sector in process.

title.narrative: Empowering Individuals in India to Create a Brighter Future (LittleBigHelp COVID-19 Emergency Pool), engagement

description.narrative:
Through computer training for tribal youth, the project empowers young people living in rural villages with basic computer skills.
In the girls’ and boys’ homes (orphanages supported by the project), vulnerable girls and boys can get away from the streets and start a new life with care, comfort, nutrition and education – and a place to call ‘home’.
At nine community centres, the project prepares children for school, support their families and raise awareness about the rights for people living in slum areas.
The project support the centre for special education, which offers care and education for children and adolescents with special needs.

title.narrative: Ghana: UNICEF Covid-19 response - IMPLEMENTATION

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

The overall medium-term objective of the project is to reduce the incidence of community transmission of COVID-19 (and by extension waterborne diseases) in poor urban settings, while increasing community resilience to disease outbreak and encouraging better health and hygiene seeking behaviour among vulnerable populations. Over the 12-month period of implementation, the project will deliver better WASH infrastructure and improved access to water, sanitation and hygiene in communities, including through health facilities and schools, to help address the preventive and curative needs of 6-8 low-income urban communities and benefitting approximately 50-80,000 people. The project will also promote hygiene and health seeking behaviour and increased access to welfare/ protection systems by women, adolescent girls and children, including in respect to SGBV. The project will also improve information systems for service delivery planning, and preparedness and response in urban settings.

sector.narrative: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation

title.narrative: Danish Support to ESMAP's Fighting COVID-19 with Sustainable Energy

description.narrative: Achieving universal energy access by 2030 and achieving decarbonization across the energy sector in support of international commitments on climate change.

ESMAP is a partnership between the World Bank and 19 partners to help low and middle-income countries reduce poverty and boost growth through sustainable energy solutions. ESMAP’s analytical and advisory services are fully integrated within the World Bank’s country financing and policy dialogue in the energy sector. Through the World Bank Group (WBG), ESMAP works to accelerate the energy transition required to achieve Sustainable Development Goal 7 (SDG7) to ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all. It helps to shape WBG strategies and programs to achieve the WBG Climate Change Action Plan targets
Health care systems in Sub-Saharan Africa are generally unequipped to deal with COVID-19. More than 70% of health facilities do not have access to reliable electricity and 30% have no electricity at all. Reliable energy is a key ingredient to ensure that COVID-19 vaccines can be stored correctly. The Danish support to ESMAP’s proposal to fight COVID-19 and strengthening health infrastructure with sustainable energy will both accelerate electrification of health facilities in Africa but also build back better by providing access to renewable energy sources.
Link to the 2020 annual report of ESMAP: https://www.esmap.org/energy-sector-management-assistance-program-%28esmap%29-annual-
N/A

title.narrative: Danish Support to ESMAP's Fighting COVID-19 with Sustainable Energy, engagement

description.narrative: The Danish Government approved the third COVID-19 emergency response package to developing countries 17 October1, 2020. In total, 13 Danish financed initiatives were endorsed by a broad political mandate and joined press release published. The package also included the present contribution to ESMAP’s COVID-19 response and amount of DKK 40.0 million. The Danish support to ESMAP’s proposal “Fighting COVID-19 and Strengthening Health Infrastructure with Sustainable Energy” will contribute to provide reliable energy to the health clinics in Sub-Saharan Africa while simultaneous demonstrate how renewable energy can replace traditional diesel generators. The Response programme aims to support at least ten low-income and fragile countries, provide 1,000 health clinics with renewable energy, improve conditions for more than 7 million patients, mobilise US$100 million IDA funding and support at least 75 energy companies to benefit from the Energy Access Relief Fund. In short, the project aims to build back better and greener by improving the health systems’ ability to fight COVID-19 and demonstrate a transition to power public institutions with green energy while at the same time support the nascent off-grid solar energy industry in Africa to get through the financial crisis.

title.narrative: Covid 19 - UNICEF - Additional storage space for protective equipment for developing countries

description.narrative:
Covid-19: Appropriation regarding "Hjælpepakke III"
Due to the COVID-19 situation, UNICEF has been faced with a challenge as regards lack of storage space for COVID-19 protective equipment for one year.
The Equipment (hazard suits, gloves, needles etc.) from, amongst other, China and India for use in Africa and Asia.
In concrete logistical terms, the need is for 5.-6.000 Square Meters which extends above the current capacty available to UNICEF. For this reason, UNICEF needs to acquire new storage space for this need. UNICEF has identified storage space which will cost around DKK 0,9 million a month - or roughly 11 mio. for a year.
The amount exceeds UNICEFs ordinary storage space budget, which is under extra pressure due to the extra costs relating to COVID-19 response. For this reason, UNICEF has requested that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs supply financing for extra storage space in these extraordinary situations.

title.narrative: DACAAR activities in Afghanistan 2021

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

The proposed project aims at improving livelihoods, health and life quality on a sustainable basis for returnees, protracted IDPs and their vulnerable host communities. By the completion of the project, beneficiaries would have improved livelihoods as measured by reduced time in collecting water and increased time spent on food production, income generation and girls’ and boys’ education, improved health as measured by a reduction in water borne diseases, and an overall improvement in the quality of life as perceived by the targeted men, women, boys and girls. The integrated nature and the diverse targeting strategy of the interventions will enable addressing of the needs and priorities of the communities from different angles; access to and use of safe drinking water coupled with open defecation free villages and improved hygiene behavior will reduce the incidence of diseases (including COVID19) which will in turn enable communities to invest increased time, energy and resources into learning new skills and engaging in various farm and off farm income generating activities offered by the intervention. The interventions planned will particularly target at risk individuals and households such as women-headed households, youth susceptible to embracing negative coping mechanisms, impoverished farmers and individuals with disability. Based on learning since outbreak of Covid-19 in March 2020the interventions for this extension period will also focus on helping communities to reduce the negative economic impact of COVID19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Danish Support to the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) 2020-2022

description.narrative: N/A

Overall objective: Contribute to building low-carbon, inclusive, climate resilient societies based on models of transformative and inclusive green growth. Specific objective: Contribute to transition to renewable energy in developing countries and emerging economies encompassing engagements supporting a green and inclusive covid-19 recovery in Africa.

The overall objective of the engagement is to contribute to building low-carbon, inclusive, climate resilient societies based on models of transformative and inclusive green growth – with a special focus on Danish SDG7 leadership through inclusive green transformation in Africa and strategically important Danish climate front-post countries where Denmark engages in green strategic partnerships.
Denmark’s financial contribution totals DKK 80 million, split between core funding for GGGI’s Strategy 2030 and earmarked funding for Danish SDG7 priorities, not least in Africa. The support will overall target inclusive, green transition, especially through renewable energy, and will integrate concerns for innovation, gender, livelihoods and jobs as well as covid-19 green recovery at country level. In addition, Denmark will engage actively with GGGI at country- and central level, in particular on the Danish priority issues and GGGI’s overall programme effectiveness.

title.narrative: Den 7. kapitaludvidelse af Den Afrikanske Udviklingsbank

description.narrative:
AfDB bidrager til økonomisk og social fremgang i Afrika. Banken yder lån til projekter og til at understøtte politikudvikling, reformer og styrkelse af institutioner i afrikanske medlemslande. I oktober 2019 indgik AfDB’s medlemslande en aftale om den største kapitaludvidelse i bankens historie på ca. 445,8 mia. kr. i indbetalt kapital fra de 27 ikke-afrikanske og 54 afrikanske medlemslande. Danmark og de øvrige nordiske lande var stærkt medvirkende til, at aftalen om kapitaludvidelsen kom til at indeholde ambitiøse mål for bankens arbejde med klima, jobs til unge, ligestilling og skrøbelighed. Danmark vil med vores bidrag til kapitaludvidelsen videre arbejde for, at banken øger sine investeringer i jobskabelse til unge og i den grønne omstilling, herunder at skabe adgang til vand og vedvarende energi i Afrika.
Kapitaludvidelsen af AfDB vil bidrage til at implementere bankens fem strategiske prioritetsområder: 1) Elektrificere Afrika; 2) Brødføde Afrika; 3) Industrialisere Afrika; 4) Integrere Afrika; 5) Forbedre livskvaliteten for den afrikanske befolkning. Dertil har AfDB et særligt fokus på de tværgående prioriteter: klima, skrøbelighed, ligestilling, god regeringsførelse, og jobs til unge. Endelig vil kapitaludvidelsen hjælpe afrikanske lande med at håndtere de akutte konsekvenser af COVID-19-krisen og sikre en grøn og inklusiv genopbygning efter krisen.
AfDB er en væsentlig kilde til finansieringen af Verdensmålene og klimadagsordenen i Afrika. Særligt kan fremhæves mål 1 (Afskaf fattigdom), mål 8 (Anstændige jobs og økonomisk vækst), mål 10 (Mindre ulighed), og mål 13 (Klimaindsats).

title.narrative: Enhancing the Safety of Journalists in Africa and the Arab Region - UNESCO (media freedom, freedom of expression)

description.narrative: N/A
N/A

With its mandate in the field of communication and information, UNESCO leads the efforts of the UN System to secure freedom of expression, media freedom, safety of journalists, access to information and combatting mis- and disinformation. The Organisation has provided an important voice to these issues during the COVID-19 pandemic and will continue to counter its negative effects in the aftermath. Denmark is a member (2019-2023) of the Intergovernmental Council of UNESCO's International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC) and is heavily engaged in UNESCO's ongoing efforts on freedom of expression, the rights and safety of journalists, and combatting disinformation. The idea is to build on the political engagement by supporting these efforts in developing countries with a financial contribution to a UNESCO-project (2021-2022), enhancing the safety of journalists in Africa and the Arab region. The project will be closely linked to UNESCO's Multi Donor Special Account on Freedom of Expression and Safety of Journalists, which is primarily funded by other Nordic countries. The effort will help respond to pertinent issues on rights and freedoms arising from the COVID-19 crisis, where the global media landscape has faced challenges including legislative changes, policies, and other measures, altering the working conditions of media professionals, during and after the Pandemic. The objective is to contribute to peace, sustainable development, and democracy through promoting human rights and the safety of journalists, in support of the UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity (UN Plan), by focusing on the UN Plan’s “Three Ps”: the prevention, protection against, and prosecution of crimes and attacks against journalists. The work of UNESCO in supporting free, pluralistic, independent, safe, and gender-sensitive media is relevant to several objectives of Denmark. title.narrative: Enhancing the Safety of Journalists in Africa and the Arab Region - UNESCO (media freedom, freedom of expression), engagement

description.narrative: With its mandate in the field of communication and information, UNESCO leads the efforts of the UN System to secure freedom of expression, media freedom, safety of journalists, access to information and combatting mis- and disinformation. The Organisation has provided an important voice to these issues during the COVID-19 pandemic and will continue to counter its negative effects in the aftermath. Denmark is a member (2019-2023) of the Intergovernmental Council of UNESCO's International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC) and is heavily engaged in UNESCO's ongoing efforts on freedom of expression, the rights and safety of journalists, and combatting disinformation. The idea is to build on the political engagement by supporting these efforts in developing countries with a financial contribution to a UNESCO-project (2021-2022), enhancing the safety of journalists in Africa and the Arab region. The project will be closely linked to UNESCO's Multi Donor Special Account on Freedom of Expression and Safety of Journalists, which is primarily funded by other Nordic countries. The effort will help respond to pertinent issues on rights and freedoms arising from the COVID-19 crisis, where the global media landscape has faced challenges including legislative changes, policies, and other measures, altering the working conditions of media professionals, during and after the Pandemic. The objective is to contribute to peace, sustainable development, and democracy through promoting human rights and the safety of journalists, in support of the UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity (UN Plan), by focusing on the UN Plan’s “Three Ps”: the prevention, protection against, and prosecution of crimes and attacks against journalists. The work of UNESCO in supporting free, pluralistic, independent, safe, and gender-sensitive media is relevant to several objectives of Denmark. Promoting the safety of journalists and combating impunity increases respect for the rule of law and reinforces good governance in ODA-eligible countries, as well as sustainable economic and human development. When media can practice its role freely and safely, including in times of elections, it ensures that political processes are open, free, and fair, thus guaranteeing a fully functioning and effective democracy.

title.narrative: Support to AmplifyChange 2021-23 - Strengthening Civil Society Advocacy for SRHR

description.narrative: A number of donors established the SRHR fund operating under the name AmplifyChange in 2014 The fund was established as a response to an identified challenge faced by small and medium sized civil society ( in developing countries to access funds from traditional donors recognizing the potential embedded in building the capacity of these small and medium si z ed CSO to advance the SRHR agenda. AmplifyChange is a well known advocate for improved policy and action on the most neglected SRHR issues F rom inception in 2014 AmplifyChange has over a 5 6 years period built its brand and an administrative set up capable of managing a large number of small and medium size projects, and developed an innovative virtual platform for knowledge sharing and tools for its grantees AmplifyChange uses a ‘call for proposals’ model in combination with activities for strengthening grantees’ organisational capacity. Since the start of the fund, about 750 grants hav e been approved to a varied range of groups, each working on a key aspect of SRHR. AmplifyChange showed its strength during the Covid 19 lock down where it quickly adapted to changing circumstances in the way of working and quickly set up webinars for its grantees and established a platform for grantees to share knowledge and ideas on how to continue working under Covid 19.
